Best practices
Defining loading behaviors is a cross-discipline task
While it may be tempting to think about loading states at a component level, there are
many technical considerations that influence how a page, region or component loads.
Therefore, before designing any of such states, it's important to understand existing
constraints that could impact load times and aim for speed optimizations whenever
possible so loading indicators aren't needed.
Consider using an indicator when waiting time is
expected to be longer than 1 second
It's important for users to feel assured that the interface is working and that the content
is loading. However, presenting loading indicators too early and too often can make the
experience feel glitchy. Consider whether some of the content can be immediately
available instead, and only present loading indicators if an operation is expected to take
longer than 1 second.
Show content as early as possible
It's not always possible to load all content immediately. In these cases, presenting at
least certain important parts quickly can help users stay engaged even if parts of the
content are not yet available.
Don't block the entire interface unless you have to
While it may be tempting to obstruct the entire interface until all content is ready to
use, the unresponsiveness can lead to frustration and abandonment. Consider which
regions of the interface need reloading, but make sure users can still operate the other
areas.
Only display one loading indicator at a time
Consider loading entire regions instead of individual components or content blocks, as
displaying multiple loading indicators can feel overwhelming and glitchy.
Component loading
There are certain cases where an action triggered by a button or
other interactive component might take a certain time to
complete. In these cases, a loading indicator contained within
such a component could give users clear feedback on the
operation.
Region loading
Q try"MA oy
Breaking up the loading of an entire interface into different
regions allows the prioritisation of certain areas to load first, as
secondary regions can be loaded progressively, when visible in
the viewport or when intentionally triggered by users.
Also, when an action triggers a reload, division by regions allows
for the rest of the interface to remain active and usable.

Indeterminate loader
Use indeterminate loaders when the time to completion of
loading is unknown. The addition of a label with a numerical
status can help users feel reassured.

e Loading (Ball loading)
Determinate loader
You can use a determinate loader when you know the time to
completion. They're most often associated with larger
background tasks that will need some time to complete.
You can also write out the progress in percentages or other
relevant units if necessary.
Component
Loading (Linear loading)
Skeleton loader
Q try"MA oy
Skeleton loaders mimic the overall shape of the content being
loaded, and can be used as placeholder for expected, repeatable
content, such as in product grids. This can help improve the
perception of faster load times.
